actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers (HSTS, X-Frame-Options, CSP, X-Content-Type-Options)
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - The absence of critical security headers (HSTS, X-Frame-Options, CSP, X-Content-Type-Options) is a valid infrastructure-level vulnerability that exposes the application to clickjacking, MIME type sniffing, XSS, and SSL/TLS downgrade attacks. This was not in the expected findings but represents a significant security control gap.

actualResults.title: Protected Resource Access Bypass via /resource Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - While related to the LFI finding, this is a distinct access control bypass vulnerability where the /resource endpoint bypasses protections implemented on /static/flag endpoint. This represents a separate authorization flaw beyond the path traversal issue and was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Server Version Information Disclosure
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - The exposure of Apache version 2.4.65 in Server headers and error pages aids attackers in reconnaissance and targeting known CVEs. This information disclosure vulnerability was not in the expected findings but represents a security weakness in server configuration.

actualResults.title: CORS Misconfiguration - Unrestricted Access-Control-Allow-Origin
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - The overly permissive CORS policy using wildcard (*) on static resources indicates a security configuration issue that could be applied to sensitive endpoints. While static resources are lower risk, this pattern indicates insecure configuration practices and was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing Brute Force Protection on Login Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - The login endpoint lacks rate limiting, account lockout, and brute force protection mechanisms, allowing unlimited authentication attempts. This is a critical authentication security control gap that enables credential stuffing and was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing CSRF Token Protection on Login Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - The login endpoint lacks CSRF tokens, cross-origin validation, SameSite cookies, and server-side CSRF validation. This represents missing security hygiene on a critical endpoint and was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Apache mod_status Endpoint Exposed with Insufficient Access Control
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - The mod_status module is enabled and responds with 403 (instead of 404) at /server-status, revealing the endpoint exists. This information disclosure allows attackers to detect mod_status and increases attack surface. This was not in the expected findings.

matched.expectedTitle: Local File Inclusion via Resource Endpoint
matched.actualTitle: Local File Inclusion (LFI) via /resource Endpoint with filename Parameter - Protected
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same vulnerability - an LFI/path traversal vulnerability in the /resource endpoint that accepts a filename parameter without proper sanitization. The actual finding confirms the expected vulnerability exists, demonstrating that arbitrary files can be served through the endpoint. While current protections block common bypass techniques, the underlying vulnerability is acknowledged as inherently risky. Both identify the same endpoint, same parameter, same vulnerability type, and same high-risk impact (unauthorized file access, information disclosure, access to sensitive system files).
